title: Why do people consider 'Alexander the Great' or 'Alexander III of Macedon' great after all those terrible things he did to the Persians? - Quora

response.answer_text: What terrible things? His troops did bring down the Persian empire, fought the Persian troops on the battlefield but did not hunt them down, did not torture or kill prisoners afterwards, did not slaughter non-combatants, did not commit genocides, rapes, sacking of private properties, destruction of temples etc. - this was the Persian attitude in Greece but not the Greek attitude in Persia. Are you sure you read THIS planet’s history? The only destruction he wrought in Persia was the calculated torching of Persepolis since he did not have the troops to continuously hold the focal point of all Persian aspirants to royal power. A regrettable event, yes- but not the wanton destruction that the Persians wrought in Greece. Get your facts straight before submitting questions!

Because he was arguably the greatest general in history, conquering an empire from the Balkans to the Punjab without losing a single battle. The morality of his actions has very little to do with it. If we're going to start judging ancient rulers by whether or not they followed the Geneva Convention, then just about everyone who lived back then would fail the test.
